comment_data.body: @gpanders are you good with referring to lsp types within the vim.Diagnostic structure?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,6 +32,9 @@ local M = {}
 --- The source of the diagnostic
 --- @field source? string
 ---
+--- The kind of the diagnostic's message
+--- @field message_kind lsp.MarkupKind

comment_data.body: Would be good to have an answer to https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/pull/1905#pullrequestreview-1942818691
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -839,6 +840,18 @@ function M.code_action(options)
       params = util.make_range_params(win, client.offset_encoding)
     end
     params.context = context
+
+    -- Don't send markup to clients that don't support it.
+    if not client.server_capabilities.textDocument.diagnostic.markupMessageSupport then
+      --- @param diagnostic lsp.Diagnostic
+      context.diagnostics = vim.iter.map(function(diagnostic)

comment_data.body:
Do I get this right that this takes the kind from the first diagnostic and then formats all messages accordingly?

What if some are text and others markdown?  That could cause to wrong highlighting
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1796,6 +1800,26 @@ function M.open_float(opts, ...)
     end
   end
 
+  if message_kind == 'markdown' then

comment_data.body: The "types" are just interfaces or "structural types", not nominal types. So sharing them every which way seems perfectly fine to me (because renaming/aliasing them later is non-breaking).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,6 +32,9 @@ local M = {}
 --- The source of the diagnostic
 --- @field source? string
 ---
+--- The kind of the diagnostic's message
+--- @field message_kind lsp.MarkupKind

comment_data.body:
Suggest simplifying this to a simple for loop

```suggestion
      for _, v in ipairs(context.diagnostics)
        if type(v.message) == 'table' then
          v.message = v.message.value
        end
      end
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -839,6 +840,18 @@ function M.code_action(options)
       params = util.make_range_params(win, client.offset_encoding)
     end
     params.context = context
+
+    -- Don't send markup to clients that don't support it.
+    if not client.server_capabilities.textDocument.diagnostic.markupMessageSupport then
+      --- @param diagnostic lsp.Diagnostic
+      context.diagnostics = vim.iter.map(function(diagnostic)
+        if type(diagnostic.message) == 'table' then
+          diagnostic.message = diagnostic.message.value
+        end
+        return diagnostic
+      end, context.diagnostics)

comment_data.body:
We've thus far avoided it successfully. Typically what we try to do is shove any LSP-specific stuff into the `lsp/diagnostic.lua` module and keep `vim.diagnostic` LSP-free. If it's just a type definition though it's probably not a big deal, and it probably doesn't make sense to replicate this type.

An alternative could be to make this a simple `boolean` (e.g. `@field plaintext boolean` or `@field markdown boolean`). That of course wouldn't extend if other markup types are added in the future though.

(Edit for clarity: I wrote this before I saw @justinmk's comment)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,6 +32,9 @@ local M = {}
 --- The source of the diagnostic
 --- @field source? string
 ---
+--- The kind of the diagnostic's message
+--- @field message_kind lsp.MarkupKind

comment_data.body:
We could loosen the relationship slightly with something like:

```lua
--- @alias vim.diagnostic.MarkupKind lsp.MarkupKind
```

Then in the future we _could_ make the `vim.diagnostic` version a superset.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -32,6 +32,9 @@ local M = {}
 --- The source of the diagnostic
 --- @field source? string
 ---
+--- The kind of the diagnostic's message
+--- @field message_kind lsp.MarkupKind

comment_data.body: Duh you're right. These diagnostics might not all have the same kind. I should instead set `message_kind` to `markdown` if _any_ one of them has Markdown content.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1796,6 +1800,26 @@ function M.open_float(opts, ...)
     end
   end
 
+  if message_kind == 'markdown' then

comment_data.body:
> I should instead set message_kind to markdown if any one of them has Markdown content.

I think the highlighting should be restricted to the messages where message_kind is markdown. Highlighting plaintext as markdown can lead to incorrect styling. E.g. unquoted variables like `_foo` with a trailing `_` later in the text would highlight the whole section.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1796,6 +1800,26 @@ function M.open_float(opts, ...)
     end
   end
 
+  if message_kind == 'markdown' then

comment_data.body: Agree; that's the whole point of declaring the format: knowing when to parse/render and when not to.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1796,6 +1800,26 @@ function M.open_float(opts, ...)
     end
   end
 
+  if message_kind == 'markdown' then

comment_regular_data.body: Note to self: Remove hardcoded protocol changes and use the generator script to pick up the upstream definitions, but we need https://github.com/microsoft/language-server-protocol/pull/1910 to be merged first.
